drug.name: Aptazapine
drug.description: Aptazapine (CGS-7525A) was a tetracyclic antidepressant developed in the 1980s. Aptazapine had noradrenergic and specific serotonergic activity. It antagonised Î±2 adrenergic receptors approximately 10 times more effectively than mianserin, antagonised 5-HT2 receptors, agonised H1 receptors, and did not affect reuptake of serotonin or norepinephrine. Although Aptazapine reached clinical trials, it was never marketed.

article.citation: Gower AJ, Broekkamp CL, Rijk HW, Van Delft AM: Pharmacological evaluation of in vivo tests for alpha 2-adrenoceptor blockade in the central nervous system and the effects of the enantiomers of mianserin and its aza-analog ORG 3770. Arch Int Pharmacodyn Ther. 1988 Jan-Feb;291:185-201.

Liebman JM, Lovell RA, Braunwalder A, Stone G, Bernard P, Barbaz B, Welch J, Kim HS, Wasley JW, Robson RD: CGS 7525A, a new, centrally active alpha 2 adrenoceptor antagonist. Life Sci. 1983 Jan 24;32(4):355-63.

drug.indication: Investigated for the treatment of depression.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as 1,4-benzodiazepines. These are organic compounds containing a benzene ring fused to a 1,4-azepine.

drug-interaction.name: Tranylcypromine
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Tranylcypromine is combined with Aptazapine.
